intro: Semecarpus nigroviridis, commonly known as the black-barked sycamore, is a deciduous tree native to the Indian subcontinent. It belongs to the family Hippocastanaceae and is characterized by its smooth, dark bark and large, palmately lobed leaves. The plant produces yellowish-green flowers followed by woody, spiny fruits containing edible seeds. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in forested areas. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
